references.B61LIG01NAUS: Ligon, J.S. 1961. New Mexico birds and where to find them. The University of New Mexico Press, Albuquerque.
references.A89ROT01USGP: Roth, S.D and J.M. Marzluff. 1989. Nest Placement and productivity of Ferruginous Hawks in western Kansas. Transactions Kansas Acad. Science 92:132-148.
references.A87SCH01USGP: Schmutz, J.K. 1987. The effect of agriculture on ferruginous and Swainson's hawks. Journal of Range Management, 40:438-440.
references.A01BAK01USGP: Bak, J. M., K. G. Boykin, B. C. Thompson, D. L. Daniel. 2001. Distribution of wintering ferruginous hawks (Buteo regalis) in relation to black-tailed prairie dog (Cynomys ludovicianus) colonies in southern New Mexico and northern Chihuahua. Journal of Raptor Research. 35:124-130.
references.A11KEE01USGP: Keeley, W. H. and M. J. Bechard. 2011. Flushing Distances of Ferruginous Hawks Nesting in Rural and Exurban New Mexico. Journal of Wildlife Management. 75: 1034-1039
references.A02CAR01USGP: Carroll, S.K., T.C. Carter, and G.A. Feldhammer. 2002. Placement of nets for bats: effects on perceived fauna. Southeastern Naturalist, 1(2):193-198.
references.N06KEO01USGP: Keough, H. L. 2006. Factors influencing breeding Ferruginous Hawks (Buteo regalis) in the Uintah Basin, Utah. Ph.D. Dissertation, Utah State University, Logan, UT.
references.A83GIL01USGP: Gilmer, D. S. and R. E. Stewart. 1983. Ferruginous Hawk populations and habitat use in North Dakota. J. Wildl. Manage. 47:146-157.
references.A03COO01USGP: Cook, R. R., J.-L. E. Cartron, and P. Polechla Dr. 2003. The importance of prairie dogs to nesting ferruginous hawks in grassland ecosystems. Wildlife Society Bulletin. 31:1073-1082.
references.A98LEA01USGP: Leary, A. W., R. Mazaika, and M. J. Bechard. 1998. Factors affecting the size of Ferruginous Hawk home ranges. Wilson Bulletin 110:198-205.
references.N75WOF01USGP: Woffinden, N. D. 1975. Ecology of the Ferruginous Hawk (Buteo regalis) in central Utah: population dynamics and nest site selection. Master's Thesis. Brigham Young Univ. Provo, UT.
references.A93RAM01USGP: Ramakka, J. M. and R. T. Woyewodzic. 1993. Nesting ecology of Ferruginous Hawk in northwestern New Mexico. Journal of Raptor Research. 27:97-101.
references.A90BEC01USGP: Bechard M. J., R. L. Knight, D. G. Smith, and R. E. Fitzner. 1990. Nest site and habitat of sympatric hawks (Buteo spp.) in Washington. Journal of Field Ornithology. 61:159-170.
references.A76HOW01USGP: Howard, R. P. and M. L. Wolfe. 1976. Range improvement practices and Ferruginous Hawks. J. Range Manage. 29:33-37.
references.R82JAS01USGP: Jasikoff, T.M. 1982. Habitat suitability index models: ferrigunous hawk. U.S.D.I. Fish Wildl. Serv. FSW/OBS-82/10.10. 18 pp.
references.A85WHI01USGP: White, C. M. and T. L. Thurow. 1985. Reproduction of ferrignous hawks exposed to controlled disturbance. Condor. 87-14-22
references.W95BEC01USGP: Bechard, Marc J. and Josef K. Schmutz. 1995. Ferruginous Hawk (Buteo regalis), The Birds of North America Online (A. Poole, Ed.). Ithaca: Cornell Lab of Ornithology; Retrieved from the Birds of North America Online: http://ida.lib.uidaho.edu:2123/bna/species/172
references.A77FIT01USGP: Fitzner, R. E., D. Berry, L. L. Boyd, and C. A. Reick. 1977. Nesting of Ferruginous Hawks (Buteo regalis) in Washington, 1974-75. Condor 79:245-249.
references.A86KON01USGP: Konrad, P. M. and D. S. Gilmer. 1986. Post fledging behavior of Ferruginous Hawks in North Dakota. Raptor Res. 20:35-39.
references.R93OLE01USGP: Olendorff, R. R. 1993. Status, biology, and management of Ferruginous Hawks: a review. Raptor Res. and Tech. Asst. Cen., Spec. Rep. U.S. Dep. Interior, Bur. Land Manage. Boise, ID.
references.A96EAK01USGP:
Eakle, W.L., E.L. Smith, S.W. Hoffman, D.W. Stahlecker, and R.B. Duncan. 1996. Results of a raptor
survey in southwestern New Mexico. Journal of Raptor Research 30(4):183-188.
references.R92ATK01USGP: Atkinson, E. C. 1992. Ferruginous hawk (BUTEO REGALIS) inventories on the Dillon Resource Area of southwest Montana: 1992. Montana Natural Heritage Program for Bureau of Land Management, Dillon Resource Area. 34 pp.

habitat_description: B. reglis inhabits: grasslands, semi-desert shrub-steppe, sagebrush rangelands, salt brush-greasewood shrublands, savannas, pasture/hay fields, riparian woodlands, and the periphery of pinyon-juniper and other woodlands (Woffinden, 1975; Fitzner et al., 1977; Jasikoff, 1982; Gilmer and Stewart, 1983; Konrad and Gilmer, 1986; Atkinson, 1992; Olendorf, 1993; Bechard and Schmutz, 1995; Leary et al., 1998; Keough, 2006). Croplands are used for foraging, but not extensive swaths of uninterrupted, tilled cropland (Schmutz, 1987; Olendorf, 1993). The species avoids forest interior, high elevations, and narrow canyons (Bechard and Schmutz, 1995).
